title: "I Don't Have Time to Help My Kid with Math" – What to Do
description: Realistic strategies for busy parents who can't spend hours on homework help.
imageAlt: Busy parent finding time for child's math

content.intro: I work full time. By the time I get home, cook dinner, and handle life, there's no energy for tutoring. Here's what I learned: I don't have to be the teacher.

sections.text: The Busy Parent Reality
Let's be honest about the math:
Spending 30-60 minutes on math tutoring? Not realistic. Not sustainable. Not necessary.
What You Actually Need to Provide
Time Required: 2 Minutes
That's your job. The app/program does the actual teaching.
Your role is logistics and encouragement, not instruction. Outsource the teaching to tools designed for it.
Strategies for Time-Strapped Parents
1. Morning Math
10 minutes with breakfast. You're making coffee anyway. They're eating anyway. Combine the time.
2. After-School Immediate
If a caregiver (grandparent, after-school program) is with them, math happens then. Not waiting for you.
3. Dinner Delay
"10 minutes of math while I finish cooking, then dinner." Parallel activities.
4. Screen Time Gate
"Math first, then iPad/TV." No negotiation. They manage themselves.
What to Use
Choose tools that don't require your involvement:

rows: App teaches, you don't have to
Quick dashboard check shows if they're on track

sections.text: Weekend Catch-Ups
If weekdays are chaos, weekends can handle:

items: Looking at weekly progress reports (5 min)
Asking "What did you learn this week?" (2 min)
Playing a quick math game together (10 min)

sections.text: 30 minutes on Sunday can cover what you couldn't do all week.
The Guilt Question

Yes, some parents have 2 hours every evening for homework help. Good for them. But a child with a busy working parent who does consistent 10-minute practice with an app will do better than a child whose parent attempts hour-long sporadic tutoring with guilt and exhaustion.
Consistency > intensity. Sustainability > heroics.

faq.question: Is 10 minutes really enough?
faq.answer: Yes, if it's daily. 10 min × 5 days = 50 min/week of focused practice. That's significant over months.

faq.question: What if my child has real math problems that need tutoring?
faq.answer: For serious struggles, consider a weekly tutor session. Still not your job to be the tutor – you can't be everything.

faq.question: I feel guilty using screens instead of teaching myself
faq.answer: Would you feel guilty using a textbook instead of writing every lesson yourself? Tools are tools. Use good ones without guilt.

cta.text: SoroKid requires minimal parent involvement – just 10-15 minutes of self-guided daily practice.

faq.question: What will I learn from this article?
faq.answer: This article covers Realistic strategies for busy parents who can't spend hours on homework help..

faq.question: Is this advice suitable for all ages?
faq.answer: The strategies discussed are primarily designed for children ages 5-12, but many principles can be adapted for different age groups.

faq.question: How long does it take to see results?
faq.answer: Results vary by child, but most parents notice improvements within 2-4 weeks of consistent practice.

faq.question: Do I need special materials or equipment?
faq.answer: Most activities can be done with everyday items. For Soroban-specific learning, the Sorokid app provides a virtual abacus.

faq.question: Can I use these methods alongside school curriculum?
faq.answer: Absolutely! These approaches are designed to complement, not replace, what children learn at school.
